# Institutional Social Responsibility

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to fulfilling its corporate social responsibilities with the goal of becoming a responsible and sustainable organization. The Authority fulfills this commitment in various areas, including promoting sustainable and environmentally conscious markets, caring for the broader community, protecting the environment, and creating a friendly workplace.

To respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced multiple measures to support individuals and businesses in need, thereby helping the Hong Kong economy weather the crisis.

# Market Environment

# Green and Sustainable Finance

Climate change is one of the major risks affecting human well-being and the sustainability of the global economy. As an important part of society, the financial system is also inevitably affected; and as a component of the financial system, banks should be more proactive in managing climate risks. In this regard, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to exploring ways to address this challenge and is implementing a number of measures announced in May 2019 to promote the development of green finance in Hong Kong. These measures include a three-phase approach to advancing the development of green and sustainable banking:

# Phase One

Establish a common framework with the industry to assess the current "green benchmarks" of banks, and collaborate with international organizations to provide technical support to Hong Kong's banking sector;

# Phase Two

Consulting the industry and other stakeholders on regulatory expectations and requirements regarding green and sustainable banking; and

# Phase Three

Focus on implementing, reviewing, and assessing the progress of banks in this regard.

On the international level, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) participates in several international organizations, including the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), the High-Level Working Group on Climate-Related Financial Risks under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Sustainable Finance Interest Group under the Banking Supervision Subgroup of the Central Bank Meeting for East Asia and the Pacific, and the International Platform on Sustainable Finance. Through its participation in these international organizations, the HKMA has the opportunity to contribute to the efforts of central banks and regulators in addressing climate change, and to draw on experiences and perspectives from other regions when developing its local framework.

The HKMA also participates in several working groups under the central bank and regulatory authorities' Green Finance Network, including the Microprudential Regulation Working Group, the Macrofinancial Working Group, and the Promoting Green Finance Working Group. In addition, the HKMA has joined two newly established working groups: the Research Working Group and the Data Gap Remediation Working Group. The Research Working Group is responsible for conducting relevant research, while the Data Gap Remediation Working Group aims to develop a comprehensive list of data items that regulatory authorities and financial institutions need to assess climate-related risks and opportunities, but currently do not have access to. Details of the HKMA's work in promoting green and sustainable banking during the year are set out in the chapter on "Banking System Stability."

In November, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the Green Commercial Banking Alliance in partnership with the International Finance Corporation (IFC), helping banks in emerging markets develop strategies to address climate change. As a founding member and the first regional executive director of the alliance, the HKMA i) promotes the development of green commercial banking in global financial markets; ii) provides a platform for commercial banks to learn from each other, acquiring the knowledge, tools, and business intelligence needed to develop their own green finance roadmaps and transform into credible green banks; iii) facilitates communication and explores cutting-edge issues to advance the global green agenda; and iv) assists alliance members in collaborating and capitalizing on the estimated $2.3 trillion in green and climate-related investment opportunities in emerging markets over the next decade, as identified by the IFC.

Locally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) collaborates with other financial regulators to coordinate the financial sector's measures in addressing climate and environmental risks. In addition to assisting the government in implementing initiatives related to the government's green bond program, the HKMA has also jointly established with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) the Inter-Agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance (Steering Group), which handles cross-sectoral regulatory and market development issues. Details of the HKMA's work this year in advancing Hong Kong as a hub for green and sustainable finance are outlined in the chapter titled "Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center."

# Inter-Agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance

The Steering Group aims to coordinate the financial sector's measures to address climate and environmental risks, accelerate the development of green and sustainable finance in Hong Kong, and support the government's climate strategy. The Steering Group was jointly established by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) in May, with other members including the Environmental Bureau, the Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, the Insurance Authority, and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

Since its establishment, the steering group has set up two technical working teams, one responsible for researching and handling cross-departmental regulatory matters, and the other for coordinating cross-agency market development efforts.

The Steering Group released its Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy in December, outlining six areas to strengthen Hong Kong's financial ecosystem and build a more green and sustainable future in the long term. The Steering Group also announced five short-term action agendas to address some of the most pressing issues in the development process.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) held a founding meeting for the supervisory group, with Mr. Stephen R. Cheung, the HKMA's Chief Executive (third from the right), serving as the co-chairman of the group.

The Steering Group released Hong Kong's Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy and five key action outlines.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) supports responsible investment, which involves integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into investment activities. As a major asset owner, the HKMA is increasingly focused on responsible investment, and this will influence how its fund managers conduct their investment activities.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Beliefs

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority believes that by appropriately emphasizing responsible investment and considering the sustainable long-term performance of various investments, it will more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund and reduce ESG-related risks associated with investment activities.

# Principles of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority

According to the guiding principles adopted by the HKMA, ESG investments are generally given priority when their risk-adjusted long-term returns are comparable to those of other investment options. As a responsible long-term investor, the HKMA incorporates the following principles of responsible investment in its investment management process, depending on the circumstances.

# Integration

The HKMA believes that ESG factors can have a significant impact on the long-term value of investment projects, and therefore integrates ESG factors into the investment analysis process to identify risks and uncover opportunities. The HKMA incorporates ESG factors into both its public market and private market investment management processes.

# Proactive Exercise of Ownership Rights

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) appropriately exercises its shareholder rights in the listed companies' shares it holds to safeguard the long-term value of its investments. The HKMA believes that responsible corporate behavior taking into account ESG factors will help create long-term shareholder value. The HKMA expects its external investment managers to actively exercise ownership rights by voting and communicating with the investee companies, thereby assisting the HKMA in fulfilling its ownership responsibilities over its investment portfolios.

# Collaboration

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to collaborating with like-minded investors and regulatory bodies to promote sound long-term investment management practices. It also participates in public events and delivers speeches to share more refined ESG operational approaches and encourage the investment community to adopt responsible investment principles.

For details on the HKMA's work on responsible investment during the year, see the chapter on "Reserve Management."

# As a proactive and responsible investor, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority oversees the ESG practices of its external investment managers.

# Monetary Authority's Expectations

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) places great emphasis on incorporating ESG factors into investment decisions and actively exercising asset ownership. To this end, the HKMA takes ESG factors into account when selecting and monitoring external investment managers. As the HKMA believes that exercising shareholder rights on listed company shares it holds is a fundamental principle for safeguarding the long-term value of its investments, it requires appointed investment managers to take the active exercise of asset ownership seriously.

# Supervision by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority

External investment managers are required to have their ESG performance assessed with regard to the listed equity portfolios they manage on behalf of the HKMA. Through a communication program, the HKMA systematically reviews the ESG practices of external investment managers across various areas, such as their ESG evaluation frameworks, communication with investee companies, and proxy voting activities. In 2020, the HKMA selected a number of external investment managers to participate in the communication program first, during which not only their ESG performance was assessed, but also whether they appropriately exercised asset ownership on behalf of the HKMA.

# Communication Outcomes

The HKMA identifies outsourced investment managers with problematic operational practices through the program and takes follow-up actions. The following are two examples.

# Case 1

The HKMA noted that the ESG framework of Investment Manager A had room for improvement, particularly in establishing a more systematic approach to evaluating investee companies. The HKMA followed up with A on this matter, after which A conducted a comprehensive review of its company policies to implement a more robust ESG framework. A also specifically appointed external consultants to provide advice on ESG procedures, reflecting a strong commitment to accelerating reforms. Additionally, A established a new ESG Committee composed of senior management, demonstrating its commitment to ESG and the support of senior management for these measures.

# Case 2

After reviewing the voting practices of stock fund manager B, the HKMA found that B's voting policy had several shortcomings and requested its ESG head to review the policy. In particular, B had previously fully supported all management proposals in its voting record, deviating from its own proxy voting guidelines. B later committed to strengthening its voting policy to meet expectations, including increasing the involvement of ESG team members and potentially voting against management in cases involving significant governance issues.

In terms of investing in the private equity market, the HKMA fulfills its responsible investment approach through its dedicated partners who actively collaborate with relevant portfolio companies on ESG matters. The HKMA has noticed that these dedicated partners consistently uphold their ESG commitments, as they believe this approach helps create long-term value for portfolio companies and ensures the sustainability of returns. The two examples listed below demonstrate how climate change risks can be managed through (i) designing modifications and utilizing innovative operational technologies, and (ii) incorporating carbon reduction factors into the construction and operation of green and sustainable warehouses. Both examples have made significant positive environmental impacts, reducing carbon emissions and avoiding harmful substances, while simultaneously improving operational efficiency through cost reduction and energy savings.

(i) The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has invested in a pest control company that adopts an environmentally friendly solution. Although traditional insecticides and chemical products can effectively kill pests, failure to promptly remove or properly dispose of the dead pests can pose a threat to public health. In addition, leakage and disposal of chemical substances can cause environmental problems. The company uses a method that does not involve biocides, reducing the use of harmful chemicals by setting up traps. The company also uses internet-connected dynamic sensors to remotely detect whether pests have been captured. With this new technology, the company can plan efficient routes to collect the captured pests, reducing travel distance and thus lowering carbon emissions. The company's approach has achieved a low level of net carbon emissions of 0.36 kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalent per dollar of net sales, approaching the average level of low-carbon industries such as legal services and software publishing, which is indeed encouraging.

(ii) The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has invested in green and sustainable warehouses. Although the construction industry is a major source of carbon emissions, the relevant warehouse developers have adopted net-zero carbon emission procedures in their overall warehouse construction and operations, and have established standards and indicators for measuring net-zero carbon emissions. The construction plans also take into account the sustainability of the materials and components used. As a result, the warehouses built are highly energy-efficient in terms of carbon reduction and possess sustainable features, including solar heating systems, electric vehicle charging facilities, natural lighting, and rainwater collection systems.

According to the assessment by independent consultants, the carbon footprint of the warehouse construction is 25.8% lower than that of a typical logistics building, on a net basis. To further offset the carbon emissions from the construction work, 32,799 trees were planted during the construction process (on a net basis). Once completed, the warehouse's daily operational carbon emissions are 26.9% lower than those of a typical warehouse.

茲證明我已審計列載於第187至289頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2020年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。
